best_practices: Always review staged changes before committing to ensure all related files are included
Write commit messages in imperative mood (add, not added or adding)
Group related changes into feature units rather than committing per file
anti_patterns: Creating commits that list development process instead of final results
Committing files individually when they belong to the same feature
Using vague commit subjects like "update code" or "fix stuff"

faq.question: Does this skill run git commit automatically?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides guidance and format rules. You run the git commit command yourself.

faq.question: What is Conventional Commits format?
faq.answer: A structured format with emoji, type, scope, and subject that makes commits easier to understand and automate changelogs.

faq.question: Can I use this with any git hosting platform?
faq.answer: Yes, Conventional Commits works with GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, and any platform that reads git history.

faq.question: Is my commit data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No, this is a prompt-based skill. Commit data stays local and is only processed by git on your machine.

faq.question: Why use emoji prefixes?
faq.answer: Emoji prefixes make commit history scannable. Team members can quickly identify the type of change at a glance.

faq.question: How does this differ from other commit tools?
faq.answer: This skill enforces result-oriented messages and feature-unit commits rather than process-oriented or file-by-file commits.
